comment_data.body: Why is this variable called `end_row`?
Well because the row where the loop ends is returned in it. I'll change it though, seems less confusing the other way around.
Why is this change include in this PR?
Dirty workspace when starting work on thisðŸ¤·ðŸ». (Check was added in #32766 but can be simplified like this.)

This will use the start of a multi-line fold, but it should be the end instead. I think it should be like this:
```suggestion
    lnum_prev = lnum_next;
```
The `lnum_next` variable may a bit misnamed here, but I can't decided how else to name it, as if I name it `lnum_end` it's too similar to `end_lnum`.
Oh, I may have named it after the `nextp` argument of `plines_win_full()`.

Yeah already considered this and I wasn't sure but I think `lnum` is correct. That sets it to the line which the last calculated height "belongs to" right? I think that is what we want to return in `max`. E.g. that will be the last (foldtext) line visible in a window (considering `start_row == topline`).

But you said at the top comment:
> "what lines take up X height"

Which sounds like it should be the last line of a fold.
May want to calculate and return `end_vcol` as well.

comment_data.body: Well technically the last line of a fold doesn't take up any height. It may be more useful to return the last line of a fold but the first line seems less surprising to me.

That'll depend on the use case, but I can't think of a concrete use case that actually uses the `end_row` return value. The current use case in LSP floating preview doesn't use that value. Did you have a use case in mind?

I intend to use it in #27855 to determine the last line in a message window (could also just use `line('w$')` for that presumably but currently the topline isn't yet what it will be when I want to calculate this...).

So yeah a use case is determining what will be the last visible line in a window when the topline is set to `start_row` but currently `topline != start_row`.

either here or in the description, would be valuable to mention this insight:

> Can be used to reduce unnecessary work, or answer question "what lines take up X height?"

comment_data.body:
1. This will call `linetabsize()` twice. Better assign its result to a variable.
2. It may be better to use `linetabsize_eol()` here.

There seems to be a naming inconsistency. `height_cur_nofill`, `folded_end` and `fill_end` refer to properties of the name line, but named in different formats. I'd suggest renaming `folded_end` and `fill_end` to `cur_folded` and `cur_fill`, as `end` may be a bit ambiguous.

This isn't correct. `lnum_end == *end_lnum` is `false` when the last `*end_lnum` is at the end of the fold, but that make it impossible to only count filler lines above the fold without counting the fold itself. I think it should be changed to `lnum > *end_lnum` instead.

I'm trying to add test for this case in #33529. This line of the test is what I'm referring to:
```lua
      eq({ all = 4, fill = 2 }, api.nvim_win_text_height(0, { end_row = 2, end_vcol = 0 }))
```
Yeah I get it now, makes sense I think. `end_vcol` having no meaning on the folded line is caught by `MIN(row_off, height_cur_nofill)` anyways.

I think there is some inconsistency with setting `end_vcol` to the number of screen columns. If `end_row` is an empty line, `end_vcol` will always be `0`, but when calling the API `end_vcol = 0` means only including filler lines above `end_row`. A similar problem applies to the case when `end_row` is a folded line, where `end_vcol` is always set to 0.

Of course, there is another problem that it is not possible to tell whether `max_height` is reached at filler lines above `end_row` or at text in `end_row`. Not sure if this should be addressed.

Maybe we don't need to try to document all these gotchas separately? I think the following would apply to all situations:
```diff
@@ -494,12 +494,10 @@ void nvim_win_set_hl_ns(Window window, Integer ns_id, Error *err)
 /// @return  Dict containing text height information, with these keys:
 ///          - all: The total number of screen lines occupied by the range.
 ///          - fill: The number of diff filler or virtual lines among them.
-///          - end_row: The row for which "max_height" is reached (first row of a
-///            closed fold), or "end_row" from {opts} if "max_height" isn't reached.
-///          - end_vcol: Number of columns used up by "end_row" to reach
-///            "max_height", or if "max_height" isn't reached, either "end_vcol"
-///            from {opts} or the number of columns "end_row" takes up on the screen.
-///            0 if "end_row" is a closed fold.
+///          - end_row: The row on which the returned height is reached (first row of
+///            a closed fold).
+///          - end_vcol: Ending virtual column in "end_row" where "max_height" or the returned
+///            height is reached. 0 if "end_row" is a closed fold.
 ///
 /// @see |virtcol()| for text width.
 Dict nvim_win_text_height(Window window, Dict(win_text_height) *opts, Arena *arena, Error *err)
```
